title: Shame of fat pic being sent round work made Sun reader Zoe lose over 9st – here’s how she did it
text:
Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments WHEN Zoe Morris was bullied at school, she had one place to turn for comfort – the kitchen cupboard. 
Crisps, chocolate and biscuits were her coping strategy but while they may have eased the pain of daily teasing, Zoe’s junk food binges saw her go from a size 10 to a size 22 in just two years. News Group Newspapers Ltd Zoe Morris managed to shed nine-and-a-half stone Collect Zoe chose to change her lifestyle once this picture circulated around the office 
Despite studying health and social care, Zoe was in denial about her extreme weight gain. 
But then a picture of her at a work event was emailed around the office and she was forced to face the fact she was dangerously obese. 
Shocked and ashamed, Zoe, who weighed 18-and-a-half stone, vowed to ditch her unhealthy habits and turn her life around. News Group Newspapers Ltd 15 She swapped her diet of crisps, chocolate and biscuits for a life-changing diet daily exercise routine 
After cutting the fat-laden snacks out of her diet, Zoe took on a challenging exercise routine that saw her partake in daily workouts. 
In just 14 months, Zoe undid years of unhealthy eating, dropping nine-and-a-half stone and seven dress sizes to weigh in at just nine stone and a stunning size 8. 
Zoe, 22, from Mansfield, Notts, says: “When I saw the picture, I couldn’t believe it was me at first. News Group Newspapers Ltd 15 The 22-year-old dropped an amazing seven dress sizes in 14 months 
“I’d been at an awards night and was picking up my NVQ in health and social care. 
“There was a photographer there but I had no idea he would send the pictures round to everyone I worked with. 
“I knew I was overweight but I’d always avoided having my picture taken and hated looking at myself in the mirror. 
“I was mortified, but it was a huge wake-up call — I knew I couldn’t live like it any more.” RELATED STORIES Bags of appeal Gemma Collins goes on a designer spree 'up West' after showing off her dramatic weight loss What a gem! Gemma Collins shows off weight loss in slimline jeans and see-through blouse and her new shorter hair NO SHRINKING VIOLET Chris Moyles reveals how he moved out of his 'fat breakfast DJ phase' to shed five stone 'We should fat shame’ Weight loss guru says fat nurses should wear badges and body acceptance campaigns are 'poisonous' SING YOURSELF SLIM Alexandra Burke reveals singing helped her shed TWO STONE JEAN-IUS Khloe Kardashian shows off her staggering three-stone weight loss as she flashes the flash in sexy new denim campaign Shocking online abuse Lisa Riley reveals cruel trolls told her she 'looks like a cancer victim' after 11-stone weightloss 
Zoe, now a teaching assistant, started overeating when she was 16 and being bullied at school. 
She says: “A group of girls started being horrible to me and I dreaded going to lessons. 
“I was always scared and had no friends — the only thing that made me feel better was eating when I got home. 
“At school, I was so terrified I wouldn’t eat much but at home I would eat anything I could — crisps, chocolate, takeaways and fizzy drinks. Collect Change . . . Zoe at her heaviest at a size 22 and 18 and a half stone News Group Newspapers Ltd 15 Zoe said she began overeating when she was bullied at school 
“I’d never exercise because I hated being out of the house on my own so I just sat in, eating.” 
By the time she was 19, Zoe struggled to fit into size 22 clothes. 
She says: “I was 19, single and fat. I felt incredibly lonely and didn’t know how to make myself feel better.” 
It was at this stage in her life that Zoe was invited to a presentation evening to receive her NVQ qualification in health and social care. 
I was always scared I had no friends 
The swanky event, at a five-star hotel in Barnsley, was the first time Zoe had been out socially in months. 
The following day the pictures from the event were emailed to all of the attendees — and when Zoe found a photograph of herself, her world came crumbling down. 
She says: “As soon as I saw the picture, my eyes filled with tears. 
“I couldn’t believe how big I looked — I hardly recognised the woman in the picture. 
“I looked horrendous. I just wanted to cover myself up and I was mortified that everyone had seen me like that.” News Group Newspapers Ltd 15 
After a sleepless night, Zoe vowed to change her life. 
She says: “I went for a run for the first time in my life the next day and chucked away all the unhealthy food in my cupboards. 
“It was hard at first but I was so determined. I forced myself to workout out every day.” 
Zoe became a fitness obsessive and even hired a personal trainer. 
She says: “My trainer got me into boxing and made me complete circuits so I would work every part of my body.” 
And after switching to a new, healthy diet, Zoe’s body changed dramatically. News Group Newspapers Ltd 
She says: “I started cooking from scratch — meat and fish with vegetables — and snacked on fruit and yoghurt. 
“It took over a year, but I managed to shift a lot of weight. 
“There were times I felt like giving up but I’d look at that picture of myself at the awards ceremony and it spurred me on. 
“If I caught a glimpse of myself in the mirror, I could hardly believe it was me.” 
After losing nine-and-a-half stone, Zoe has returned to college and says her newfound confidence means she can stand up to bullies. News Group Newspapers Ltd 15 
She says: “I feel so confident in myself and my body. I’ve had no trouble with bullies but if I did, I’d have the strength to stop them now. 
“Losing weight has helped me find a boyfriend, who I’ve been dating for ten months now. It has changed my life. 
“I‘m a new person and I’m happier than I’ve ever been. 
“I still keep the picture of myself at the awards ceremony and when I look at it, it reminds me how far I’ve come. 
“Without that picture, who knows how much longer I’d have been miserable and fat.” Take on Zoe’s flab-busting workout 
If you’ve been inspired by Zoe’s weight loss story, here’s how to do it yourself. 
Perform each exercise four times, three to four times per week. Burpee 
Get into a press-up position. 
Keeping your arms straight, bring alternate knees towards the chest as fast as you can. 
Jump your feet forward to the squat position then leap up.
